--- Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> Which would suggest that you need a proportional
> comparison. 

Right...which is the idea behind dividing by the
larger chromosome length, per Ken's original formula.

> The problem with this of course is that we allow
> large chromomses to 
> have large differences and still be within the same
> species. 

As long as it's proportional, I don't see the problem.
 Chromosomes that vary by %20, for example, no matter
what size they are, would be placed in different
species.  

> Is this what you mean by 'normalizing the chromosome
> length'? 

Yeah, that's it exactly.

> I think it was Ken who suggested that perhaps it
> would be better to turn 
> the whole technique on its head. Perhaps we should
> specify an optimal 
> number of species we would like (based on population
> size), calculate a 
> 'compatibility' number for each member of the
> population and then divide 
> them up into that number of species. 

Yes, Ken talks about dynamic thresholding in the NEAT
Users FAQ.  This seems like a reasonable approach, but
leads to a couple of points.

The philosophy behind speciation then shifts from:

--species are subgroups that vary topologically by a
particular amount

to:

--a species is not defined as much by topological
difference as by the number of species threshold

That is, in the second case, a given species could
have much more or much less topological difference
between its individuals.  This approach seems less
desirable to me, since it seems less
biologically-inspired.  You're enforcing an arbitrary
division of the population, rather than defining
species primarily by a distance function.

If you do use dynamic thresholding and define a set
number of species, this approach then leads to the
question: What is a good number of species for a
population?

And should the number of species allowed then be
proportional to the population size?  

Derek
